newsitem.title: USA: In Miami Beach, crossdressers blend right in.
newsitem.headline: In Miami Beach, crossdressers blend right in.

text.p: Slipping on a skirt may sound like a strange way for a man fleeing the FBI to elude detection, but in gender-bending Miami Beach even a cross-dressing multiple killer could blend right in.

The possibility that Andrew Cunanan, prime suspect in the murder of Italian fashion icon Gianni Versace, may be wearing a dress as he attempts to evade a massive manhunt has angered and scared transvestites in this bohemian enclave, though.

"Everybody's very upset and very scared. We're all on the lookout," said a local drag queen, who asked not to be named. "We have pictures all over the club and we're all asking people to watch out for him."

Nearly a week after Versace's murder, an army of local and state police and FBI agents were still hunting America's most wanted man. Cunanan is also a suspect in four killings in northern U.S. states since April.

Versace was shot twice in the head last Tuesday on the steps of his oceanfront mansion among the Art Deco hotels of south Florida's hedonist heaven: the rollerblading, jet-set hotspot known as South Beach.

Cunanan has been likened to a chameleon for his ability to change his looks. The wanted poster circulated by the FBI has several pictures of the alleged "spree killer" looking markedly different in each one.
Miami Beach Police during the weekend issued a statement saying Cunanan may have shaved his body hair and begun disguising himself as a woman to evade the dragnet.
"I think it would be easy for him. He looks like everybody we know," said Melanie Morningstar, a writer with "The Wire," a weekly newspaper catering to the South Beach gay community.
"Put a wig on him and it would be a breeze."

"You see everything here. We have a lot of men that come in in drag and there's a large transvestite population, so he could blend right in," Jeff Walter, manager of the Pleasure Emporium sex shop on Miami Beach where Cunanan is believed to have shopped, told CNN.

South Beach, which has transformed itself from a tattered 1980s refuge for Jewish retirees and criminal immigrants to a glittery, jet-set epicentre for models and movie stars, also is one of America's gender-bending meccas.

Hundreds of people lined up for a recent drag club opening. With some 50 drag performers making the rounds of South Beach clubs such as Hombre and Twist, and a gay community numbering some 12,000 bolstered by thousands of monthly tourists, the drag scene is one of America's most vibrant.

Speciality clothing and shoe shops carry multi-coloured, man-sized platform boots and extra-large dresses. Wig shop windows are filled with bouffant neon-green and purple hairpieces and proudly display their drag clientele in photo arrays plastered on the walls.
At Lucky Cheng's, a South Beach dinner theatre, the waitresses are really waiters with names like Chyna Girl and Judy Too Much who perform cabaret numbers between rounds.
With its laissez-faire attitude and multitude of strangers, South Beach would be an ideal place for a transient transvestite to get lost.
"Most people come for a week and stay for five years," Morningstar said. "And if you're pretty like he (Cunanan) is, you're accepted automatically."

In a community where theatrical, even outrageous makeup and clothing is the norm, a man could dress as a woman and win acceptance, at least for a while, said University of Miami sociologist Joan Alway, who specialises in gender issues.
"There's a strong element in that community that prizes or values the theatricality of it. There's an element where cross dressing and performing is tolerated and accepted," she said.
"In that sense, I think it could be easy for a while to pass or participate without close examination."
